title: Member Lecture: The Journey of the Noble Dos Aguas Armory
title_display: Member Lecture: The Journey of the Noble Dos Aguas Armory
hero_caption: Garniture for Field and Foot Tourney at the Barriers (detail), about 1575. Milan. George F. Harding Collection
short_description: Curator of Applied Arts of Europe Jonathan Tavares tells the tumultuous story of how the remains of a noble Valencian family's armory made its way to the Art Institute.
list_description: Curator of Applied Arts of Europe Jonathan Tavares tells the tumultuous story of how the remains of a noble Valencian family's armory made its way to the Art Institute.
description:
Among the great treasures in the museum's Deering Family Galleries of Medieval and Renaissance Art, Arms, and Armor are the stunning remains of a noble Valencian family's Renaissance armory. The armory is a testament to the wealth and power of the Spanish Golden Age, and the story of its survival and journey to Chicago in 1927 is filled with obstacles and intrigue. Curator of Applied Arts of Europe Jonathan Tavares highlights the armory's riches and tells the tale of how a steadfast assistant at the Metropolitan Museum and a bold Chicago politician helped make the acquisition possible. 

Please note that this is an in-person event that takes place at the museum.

In accordance with state and City of Chicago guidelines, visitors to the museum are no longer required to wear masks or provide proof of vaccination. Anyone who would like to continue to wear a mask is welcome to do so. Learn more about our visiting policies and what to expect.

If you have any questions about programming, please reach out to museum-programs@artic.edu.

Closed captioning will be available for this program. For questions related to accessibility accommodations, please email access@artic.edu.
